definition: (in ancient times) sacrificial animal (cow, sheep or pig)

sentences.english: Why would you want to keep your emotions at arms length?
sentences.chinese: 痛苦是因爲你抓得太牢不想鬆手。

sentences.english: Pain is where you hold on too tightly.
sentences.chinese: 痛苦是因爲你抓得太牢不想鬆手。

sentences.english: Be careful of the handle — it's not very well attached.
sentences.chinese: 當心那個把手，它接得不太牢。

definition: the three sacrificial animals (originally cow, sheep and pig; later pig, chicken and fish)

pair of annual sacrificial ceremonies held by the emperor in ancient times: one in the southern suburbs of the capital (bringing offerings to Heaven) and another in the northern suburbs (with offerings to Earth)
to offer sacrifices to the gods or ancestors
to offer sacrifices to the gods
to host a banquet/feast/banquet/ceremony of sacrifice
six domestic animals, namely: pig, cow, sheep, horse, chicken and dog
a stand for food at sacrifice
Rites and Ceremonies, part of the Confucian Classic of Rites 禮記|礼记[Li3 ji4]
